Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format:

YEAR-MONTH-DAY-title.MARKUP

Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and MARKUP is the file extension representing the format used in the file. After that, include the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

entry.title: Bash cheat-sheet
entry.content:
If you are not a daily bash scripter, you may forget how to do certain operations. This cheat-sheet contains the most common tasks that you may want to do.

Check if given commands exists

``` 
$ command -v curl > /dev/null || echo "Curl not installed"
```

</div>### Common string tests


```

# empty string?
[[ -z STRING ]]

# non empty string?
[[ -n STRING ]]

# strings are equal?
[[ STRING == STRING ]]

# strings aren't equal?
[[ STRING != STRING ]]
```

</div>### Common file tests


```

# exists?
[[ -e FILE ]]

# directory?
[[ -d FILE ]]

# file?
[[ -f FILE ]]

# executable?
[[ -x FILE ]]
```

</div>### Test if environment variable is set


```

[[ -z "${DEPLOY_ENV}" ]]

# example
[ -z "${HOST}" ] && HOST=localhost
```

</div>### Range loops


```

# C-like (undefined in sh)
for ((i = 0 ; i < 100 ; i++)); do
  echo $i
done

# standard
for i in $(seq 1 100); do
    echo "Welcome $i"
done
```

</div>### Conditional execution


```

$ git commit && git push
$ git commit || echo "Commit failed"
```

</div>### Test if command succeeded/failed


```

if some_command; then
    echo command returned true
else
    echo command returned some error
fi

if ! some_command; then
    echo command returned some error
else
    echo command returned true
fi
```

</div>### Directory of the script


```

SCRIPT_DIR=$(dirname "$0")
```

</div>## Resources

- https://devhints.io/bash

entry.title: The new kid on the block â€“ golang

link.title: The new kid on the block â€“ golang

entry.content:
Do you remember my article about the speed of sorting large data chunk in different languages? Of course you donâ€™t. So, I advice you to go through that article as there is a description of the test procedure. However, today Iâ€™m going to extend this benchmark by testing go language. The results will be surprisingâ€¦

Letâ€™s re-execute the test. This time Iâ€™ll be using a dedicated script run_experiment.sh which does all whatâ€™s needed and prints results in a friendly way:

``` 
$ ./run_experiment.sh 
Starting tests...
Language             Records #     Bulding time  Sorting time  Testing time  Total time        RSS memory usage
cpp optimized          100,000,000 B:   1.027 s, S:  10.312 s, T:   0.011 s, Total:  11.500 s, Mem: 1.5 GB (1565736 kB)
cpp debug              100,000,000 B:   2.496 s, S:  54.936 s, T:   0.059 s, Total:  58.890 s, Mem: 1.5 GB (1565672 kB)
c optimized            100,000,000 B:   0.899 s, S:  31.997 s, T:   0.033 s, Total:  33.060 s, Mem: 3.0 GB (3126412 kB)
c debug                100,000,000 B:   1.707 s, S:  39.647 s, T:   0.042 s, Total:  41.660 s, Mem: 3.0 GB (3126492 kB)
go                     100,000,000 B:   0.686 s, S:  29.685 s, T:   0.031 s, Total:  30.750 s, Mem: 1.5 GB (1614968 kB)
java                   100,000,000 B:   1.793 s, S:  71.187 s, T:   0.078 s, Total:  78.480 s, Mem: 3.9 GB (4062140 kB)
python                  20,000,000 B:  25.476 s, S:  50.473 s, T:   0.148 s, Total: 147.800 s, Mem: 9.0 GB (9466744 kB)
```

</div>Here is the visualization.

All sources including supporting scripts and gnuplot script are available on my [github](https://github.com/rrowniak/blog/tree/master/sorting_big).

Ok, tests have passed, so now itâ€™s time to review the results and draw the conclusions.

- C++ optimized test program is the fastest one. No surprise here.
- C++ with debug symbols enabled â€“ isnâ€™t performing well. **If youâ€™re looking for speed, debug symbols need to be switch off.**
- C program. Not a big difference between optimized and debug version. Relatively slow in comparison to C++. That might be due to a different sorting algorithm used and inability to inline the comparison function. Another unpleasant surprise **is memory consumption which is double in comparison to** C++. The algorithm that is used when calling qsort (merge sort?) has apparently O(n) memory complexity.
- Go. Very good results! Memory consumption like C++ version and **faster than C optimized program!** Of course, it doesnâ€™t mean that Go is faster than C in general, just for this task it performs better (better sorting algo).
- Java. Iâ€™d expect that Java will produce the results similar to Goâ€™s and vice versa.
- Python. Very high memory consumption and pretty slow execution time. It requires 9GB of memory while theoretical minimum is 1,5 GB (C++ and Go). For doing such tasks, specialized libraries will be needed (e.g. scipy).

entry.title: Tip of the day: SSH Key-Based Authentication

link.title: Tip of the day: SSH Key-Based Authentication

entry.content:
This type of authentication is considered to be among the most secured ones. You can setup this config in two steps.

First, you need to generate a public/private key pair. Use default location. Be careful to not override existing keys.

<pre class="wp-block-code">```
$ ssh-keygen


Then, install a public key on your server:


```
ssh-copy-id username@remote_host
```
```

If that for some reason does not work, use more manual approach:

```

```
$ cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub | ssh username@remote_host "mkdir -p ~/.ssh && cat >> ~/.ssh/authorized_keys"
```
```

Youâ€™ll find more details [here](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-configure-ssh-key-based-authentication-on-a-linux-server).

entry.title: Learning awk by examples
entry.content:
awk is a powerful Linux/Unix tool that simplifies your life when it comes to parsing text files/outputs, doing various text manipulation, or, whatâ€™s surprising to the newbies, doing certain calculations without using Excel. Letâ€™s get started!

##

Example 1 â€“ Change output on the fly

Suppose that you want to get 4 biggest files in /etc/init.d and display their names together with associated sizes. Letâ€™s start from something like that:

<pre class="wp-block-code">```bash
$ ls -l /etc/init.d/ | sort -nrk 5 | head -n4


The above combination might give you the following output:


```bash
$ ls -l /etc/init.d/ | sort -nrk 5 | head -n4
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 9138 gru  3  2018 openvpn
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 6872 paÅº 11  2019 udev
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 6032 wrz  7  2020 virtualbox
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 5574 lis  5  2019 alsa-utils
```
```

Well, weâ€™re not quite there, too many columns. Here comes *awk*:

```

```bash
awk '{ print $5, "bytes:", $9 }'
```
```

Which simply prints column number 5, short text and finally column number 9:

```

```bash
$ ls -l /etc/init.d/ | sort -nrk 5 | head -n4 | awk '{ print $5, "bytes:", $9 }'
9138 bytes: openvpn
6872 bytes: udev
5658 bytes: nfs-common
5574 bytes: alsa-utils
```
```

## Example 2 â€“ parse /proc/cpuinfo and calculate total amount of CPUs and cores

*/proc/cpuinfo* contains a lot of useful information about CPU(s) that are visible by the kernel. This file may be long, a few first lines are shown below:

```

```bash
processor       : 0
vendor_id       : GenuineIntel
cpu family      : 15
model           : 6
model name      : Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-2650 v4 @ 2.20GHz
stepping        : 1
microcode       : 0x1
cpu MHz         : 2199.996
cache size      : 16384 KB
physical id     : 0
siblings        : 1
core id         : 0
cpu cores       : 1
apicid          : 0
initial apicid  : 0
```
```

But weâ€™re interested only in a short summary â€“ CPUs and cores amount. Simple and a bit hacky awk script that does the job:

```

```bash
awk '
{
    # regex matching, we could alternatively
    # write $1 == "processor"
    if ($1 ~/processor/) {
        stats["processors"]++;
    }

    # tricky part: "cpu cores" is actually interpreted as
    # two columns!
    if ($1 == "cpu" && $2 == "cores") {
        stats["cores"] += $4;
    }
}
END {
    # iterate over associative array and print
    # key-value pairs
    for (s in stats) {
        print s , ":", stats[s];
    }
}
' /proc/cpuinfo
```
```

The output:

```

```bash
processors : 24
cores : 24
```
```

## Example 3: pretty formatting

Sometimes we want a better tool than `print "str1", $1, ...` . Here comes a built-in C-like function `printf`:

```

```bash
awk 'BEGIN {
    PI=3.14159
    printf("%s: int(%.2f) = %d\n", "Int function", PI, int(PI));
}'
```
```

Output:

```

```bash
Int function: int(3.14) = 3
```
```

This example isnâ€™t very practical in this shape but Iâ€™m pretty sure that you know whatâ€™s going on and how to use that example in real world scenarios.

## Example 4: get rid of Excel! Playing with CSV.

Consider the following CSV file:

```

```bash
"Sell","List","Living","Rooms","Beds","Baths","Age","Acres","Taxes"
142,160,28,10,5,3,60,0.28,3167
175,180,18,8,4,1,12,0.43,4033
129,132,13,6,3,1,41,0.33,1471
138,140,17,7,3,1,22,0.46,3204
232,240,25,8,4,3,5,2.05,3613
135,140,18,7,4,3,9,0.57,3028
150,160,20,8,4,3,18,4.00,3131
```
```

Our task is to calculate the average age (column 7). With *awk* this is easy:

```

```bash
awk 'BEGIN {
    count = 0;
    sum = 0;
    # define custom field separator
    FS=","
}
{
    # skip first line
    if (NR == 1) {
        next;
    }

    # skip empty or invalid lines
    if (NF < 7) {
        next;
    }

    count++;
    sum += $7
}
END {
    printf("Average age: %.1f years\n", sum / count)
}
' example.csv
```
```

Output:

```

```bash
Average age: 23.9 years
```
```

## Example 5: Treat units and prefixes

Letâ€™s try to display all directories and files in the home directory which take >= 1GB of disk space and sum them up. Good starting point would be:

```

```bash
$ du -hd1 ~ | head -n -1
12G     /home/rr/Music
1,5G    /home/rr/.config
46M     /home/rr/Pictures
4,0K    /home/rr/Public
752M    /home/rr/Documents
4,0K    /home/rr/.ssh
793M    /home/rr/STM32Cube
5,2G    /home/rr/.cache
...
```
```

Now we have to pick up those with size >= 1G. Let *awk* do the job:

```

```bash
du -hd1 ~ | head -n -1 | awk '$1 ~ /[0-9]*G/ {
    # get rid of following "G"
    val = substr($1, 0, length($1) - 1)
    
    # replace , with .
    # numbers with . decimal sep will be handled correctly
    # (sub available in gawk and nawk)
    sub(/,/, ".", val)
    
    sum += val
    
    print $1, "\t", $2
}
END {
    out = sum "G"
    sub(/\./, ",", out)
    print "total:", out
}'
```
```

Have you noticed a new syntax: `$1 ~ /[0-9]*G/ {...}` ? This says â€execute code in the brackets only when condition `$1 ~ /[0-9]*G/` is fulfilled. In our case â€“ select a line where first column ends with G.

Results:

```

```bash
12G      /home/rr/Music
1,6G     /home/rr/.config
5,2G     /home/rr/.cache
51G      /home/rr/VirtualBoxVMs
6,8G     /home/rr/Downloads
12G      /home/rr/dev
7,6G     /home/rr/apps
total: 96,2G
```
```

## Built in variables

Weâ€™ve been using some of them. More built-in variables below:

`FS `â€“ The Input Field Separator Variable (defaulted to â€ â€)

`OFS `â€“ The Output Field Separator Variable

`NF `â€“ The Number of Fields Variable

`NR `â€“ The Number of Records Variable (lines)

`RS `â€“ The Record Separator Variable (defaulted to â€\\nâ€)

`ORS `â€“ The Output Record Separator Variable

`FILENAME `â€“ The Current Filename Variable

## Conclusions

This article shows only a few problems that can be solved using *awk*. However, I strongly recommend you to get familiar with this tool by reading a good article that gives you solid understanding. For example, you can have a look at[ this excellent intro](https://www.grymoire.com/Unix/Awk.html) to awk by Bruce Barnett.

I was using standard commands to produce example data. Itâ€™s likely that you could figure out how to avoid using awk in these examples! But thatâ€™s not the point â€“ the intention is to show awk potential. In real word you will be dealing with various kind of data â€“ then awk should be your primary tool in your toolbox.

entry.title: Tip of the day: gcc address sanitizer

link.title: Tip of the day: gcc address sanitizer

entry.content:
Today Iâ€™m going to show you how effectively solve painful issues related to memory corruption occurrences.

Letâ€™s start from the example. Consider the following code:

<pre class="wp-block-code">```cpp
#include <iostream>

int array[2];
int table[2];

int main(int argc, char** argv)
{   
    array[2] = 11;

    if (table[0] == 0) {
        std::cout << "Obvious!" << std::endl;
    } else {
        std::cout << "Not really... Something is wrong" << std::endl;
        std::cout << table[0] << " vs " << array[2] << std::endl;
    }

    return array[0];
}


And corresponding makefile:


```bash
CPPFLAGS = -g -Wall
LDFLAGS = -g
LDLIBS = -lm -ldl

test: test.o
    g++ $(LDFLAGS) -o test test.o $(LDLIBS)

test.o: test.cpp
    g++ $(CPPFLAGS) -c test.cpp

clean:
    @rm test test.o
```
```

Letâ€™s build & execute the program:

```
